standard_metadata.standard_description: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Find missing length when given area of a parallelogram

question.content: The parallelogram shown below has an area of $24$ units$^2$.    **Find the missing height.**  $h = $  units

images.alt: A parallelogram. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is 6 units and the height of the parallelogram is labeled h units. The diagonal side length is 5 units.

hints.content: Let's set up an equation using the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of a parallelogram} &=  \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ 24&= 6 \cdot h \\\\ 24&= 6h \\\\ \dfrac{24}{\blueD{6}}&= \dfrac{6h}{\blueD{6}} ~~~~~~~\text{divide both sides by } {\blueD{ 6}}\\\\ \dfrac{24}{\blueD{6}}&= \dfrac{\cancel{6}h}{\blueD{\cancel{6}}}\\\\ h &=\dfrac{24}{\blueD{6}}\\\\ h &=4\end{align}$
The answer:  $h = 4$ units

question.content: The parallelogram shown below has an area of $21$ units$^2$.    **Find the missing height.**  $h = $  units

images.alt: A parallelogram. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is 7 units and the height of the parallelogram is labeled h units. The diagonal side length is 5 units.

hints.content: Let's set up an equation using the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of a parallelogram} &=  \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ 21&= 7 \cdot h \\\\ 21&= 7h \\\\ \dfrac{21}{\blueD{7}}&= \dfrac{7h}{\blueD{7}} ~~~~~~~\text{divide both sides by } {\blueD{ 7}}\\\\ \dfrac{21}{\blueD{7}}&= \dfrac{\cancel{7}h}{\blueD{\cancel{7}}}\\\\ h &=\dfrac{21}{\blueD{7}}\\\\ h &=3\end{align}$
The answer:  $h = 3$ units

question.content: The parallelogram shown below has an area of $54$ units$^2$.    **Find the missing height.**  $h = $  units

images.alt: A parallelogram. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is 9 units and the height of the parallelogram is labeled h units. The diagonal side length is 8 units.

hints.content: Let's set up an equation using the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of a parallelogram} &=  \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ 54&= 9 \cdot h \\\\ 54&= 9h \\\\ \dfrac{54}{\blueD{9}}&= \dfrac{9h}{\blueD{9}} ~~~~~~~\text{divide both sides by } {\blueD{ 9}}\\\\ \dfrac{54}{\blueD{9}}&= \dfrac{\cancel{9}h}{\blueD{\cancel{9}}}\\\\ h &=\dfrac{54}{\blueD{9}}\\\\ h &=6\end{align}$

question.content: The parallelogram shown below has an area of $140$ units$^2$.    **Find the missing base.**  $b = $  units

images.alt: A parallelogram. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is labeled b units and the height of the parallelogram is 10 units. The diagonal side length is 12 units.

hints.content: Let's set up an equation using the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of a parallelogram} &=  \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ 140&= b \cdot 10 \\\\ 140&= 10b \\\\ \dfrac{140}{\blueD{10}}&= \dfrac{10b}{\blueD{10}} ~~~~~~~\text{divide both sides by } {\blueD{ 10}}\\\\ \dfrac{140}{\blueD{10}}&= \dfrac{\cancel{10}b}{\blueD{\cancel{10}}}\\\\ b &=\dfrac{140}{\blueD{10}}\\\\ b &=14\end{align}$
The answer:  $b = 14$ units

question.content: The parallelogram shown below has an area of $60$ units$^2$.    **Find the missing base.**  $b = $  units

$\begin{align} \text{Area of a parallelogram} &=  \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ 60&= b \cdot 10 \\\\ 60&= 10b \\\\ \dfrac{60}{\blueD{10}}&= \dfrac{10b}{\blueD{10}} ~~~~~~~\text{divide both sides by } {\blueD{ 10}}\\\\ \dfrac{60}{\blueD{10}}&= \dfrac{\cancel{10}b}{\blueD{\cancel{10}}}\\\\ b &=\dfrac{60}{\blueD{10}}\\\\ b &=6\end{align}$

question.content: The parallelogram shown below has an area of $28$ units$^2$.    **Find the missing base.**  $b = $  units

images.alt: A parallelogram. The segment representing the height of the parallelogram is in the middle of the figure, splitting the figure in 2 parts. The base of the parallelogram is labeled b units and the height of the parallelogram is 7 units. The diagonal side length is 8 units.

hints.content: Let's set up an equation using the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of a parallelogram} &=  \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ 28&= b \cdot 7 \\\\ 2&8= 7b \\\\ \dfrac{28}{\blueE{7}}&= \dfrac{7b}{\blueE{7}} &\text{Divide both sides by } {\blueE{ 7}\text{.}}\\\\ \dfrac{28}{\blueE{7}}&= \dfrac{\cancel{7}b}{\blueE{\cancel{7}}}\\\\ 4 &=b \end{align}$
The answer:  $b = 4$ units
